author: Peter Dominiczak
title: Tory MPs criticise Government over 'cap' on child refugees
text:
Tory MPs criticise Government over 'cap' on child refugees Amber Rudd, the Home Secretary Credit: PA Peter Dominiczak , Political Editor 9 February 2017 • 1:36pm 
T heresa May is facing a backlash from Conservative MPs after the Government decided to cap the number of lone child refugees being brought to Britain. 
At least three senior Tory MPs have openly criticised the Government over the issue, with one even calling for a Judicial Review against the decision, which was announced by Amber Rudd, the Home Secretary. 
Ministers have announced that just 350 children will be brought to the UK under the Dubs Amendment - far fewer than the 3,000 originally expected. 
MPs compared the decision to Donald Trump's controversial travel ban in America. Watch | Child refugees 'pushed-back' trying to cross Serbian border 01:19 
I t prompted a backlash from MPs, with Dianne Abbott, Labour’s shadow Home Secretary, questioning how Ms Rudd can “live with herself”. 
Conservative MPs including David Burrowes, Heidi Allen and Will Quince have all raised concerns about the Government’s reversal. 
Ms Allen said it was a “very, very poor result” and said she would back a Judicial Review of the decision. 
Mr Burrowes accused Conservative ministers of having “cut and run from child refugees”. Watch | Drone footage reveals scale of child refugee camp in Iraq 00:28 
H e said that when MPs and peers last year voted to set up the scheme “Parliament did not intend to set a time a limit on our compassion for vulnerable child refugees in Europe”. 
Mr Quince said that the cap had made him “sad and disappointed”. 
Faced with a rebellion in the House of Lords, then prime minister David Cameron announced last year that he would accept the Dubs Amendment and settle more child refugees. Watch | PM signals U-turn over unaccompanied child refugees 01:41 
O n Wednesday, ministers quietly announced that 200 children have been brought in under the scheme, and that it will close after another 150 are settled in the UK. 
In Parliament Ms Abbott attacked Ms Rudd, saying: "How does she live with herself, leaving thousands of children subject to disease, people trafficking, squalor and hopelessness?" 
Ms Abbott said many children currently in France were not being cared for and had resorted to sleeping on the streets and in informal encampments. 
She added: "The worst thing about this Government's failure to step up to the totality of the refugee crisis is the children." 
In reply, Ms Rudd said it was the children that mattered most and it was "an absolutely disgraceful" situation on the borders of Europe, due to the amount of people being trafficked. 
Ms Rudd also told her critics to reconsider their “high moral tone”. 
Labour's Pat McFadden said: "I want to ask [Ms Rudd] what signal she thinks this sends to the world in the wake of the announcement last week from President Trump, in a different context. 
"There are always those who will say look after our own, charity begins at home, Britain first, America first, France first, and so on. 
"Does she really want us to be aligned with that sentiment, or a different one?" 
There was controversy last year after MPs raised concerns that a number of the child refugees coming to Britain were in fact adults. Follow Telegraph News
